texts.shortText: Often spelt with a single ‘i’ but we follow WoRMS spelling here by giving a double ‘i’. The subspecies given by Clark and Courtman- Stock are no longer recognized.

This species has between 10 and 22 (but usually 16-20) rather slender arms that are held curved over the body. Each arm has only 10-22 regularly-spaced lateral branches (pinnules). On the upper surface of the body the ambulacral grooves converge on the mouth, which is situated distinctly off-centre, whereas the anus (situated on a conical process) occupies the central position. On the underside there 12-25 fairly-stout attachment cirri. Colour is extremely variable, ranging from white to pink, blue or orange and often variegated.

Global: Widespread across Indian and Pacific Oceans.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.

Found in low intertidal pools and under rocks and overhangs, but most abundant on shallow reefs, where it can occur in the open in dense and extensive beds, often mixed with the similar-looking Southern feather-star Annamatra occidentalis, with which it is often confused (see below). Like most feather stars capable of swimming using a slow, graceful up and down movement of the arms if displaced from the reef. As the group name suggests, the arms are brittle and easily broken, but are quickly regenerated. Individuals with some shorter arms, or a reduced number of arms, are thus regularly encountered.

The arms are extended upwards into the water column to intercept floating plankton of other organic particles. Each pinnule is lined with tubefeet, which are held erect to form a mesh. The tubefeet grasp passing particles and pass them to an ambulacral groove running along the length of the arm, along which cilia propel a string of mucus and food particles to the mouth, which is situated on the upper surface of the central disc. A fairly simple U-shaped gut fills most of the small body and ends in an anus that is raised on a cone close to the mouth and also on the upper surface.

Details unknown for this species, but sexes separate and the gonads are located in the basal pinnules, rather than in the small body itself. When the gametes are mature the pinnules rupture and release the eggs and sperm into the water column, where they develop as planktonic larvae before settling back onto suitable substrata. Newly settled larvae are stalked (like many fossil crinoids), but the stalk is lost as they enter the adult stage.

Easily confused with the Southern feather-star Annametra occidentalis but usually has more arms (10-22, but usually 16-20, vs 10). Also that species has the mouth central and the anal cone displaced to one side of the upper body surface. The two species are most easily distinguished by the very different number of ventral cirri, which are 12-25 in C. wahlberghii and 35-40 in A. occidentalis. In practice though, very few photographers turn specimens over and count their cirri, so the identity of species in , many published images is suspect! It would be a valuable study to properly identify the distribution patterns of these two species and to determine the relative abundances, size ranges and habitat preferences (and to record the range and proportions of different arm numbers and colour forms in each species).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 228).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 11).
